title: Will negotiations on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) be completed in 2016?
preds: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-12-09/china-championed-asia-trade-pact-gains-traction-in-jakarta-talks "Our imminent exit from TPP has energized the 16 nations negotiating the China-backed RECP  to accelerate their efforts.   They neared agreement on protections and assistance related to small-and-medium-sized enterprises, and also made progress on competition policy.  Matters such as intellectual property rights, as well as trade in goods and services, remain unresolved.  "The next talks will be held in Japan in February.
What looked promising at the beginning of the year proved too much for the RECP negotiators.

Tang (2016) states that: The conclusion of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade agreement last week could speed up talks on its lesser-known Asia-wide equivalent, trade analysts say. 
Negotiators working on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) are currently in the middle of a week-long meeting, the 10th of its kind, in Busan, South Korea. 
"I am not 100 percent sure whether the RCEP deal will be struck as soon as this week but the stakes are now higher for RCEP members, especially those that are not in the TPP, because they realize that they are losing out," said Kaewkamol Pitakdumrongkit, assistant professor at the S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies (RSIS), Nanyang Technological University (NTU). 
"This mindset of 'losing out' could tempt these non-TPP countries in RCEP to reach a deal very soon," she added in an email interview with CNBC. 
Deborah Elms, executive director at Asia Trade Centre, agrees: "The TPP has been viewed [with a fair amount of skepticism] by many of the RCEP countries. They were working towards a deadline at the end of the year ... but they were not under a great deal of pressure. Now that the TPP is closed, I think the pressure for some kind of high quality result out of RCEP is likely to mount." 
According to South Korea's Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy, countries participating in the regional free trade deal will this week discuss guidelines for market liberalization and draw up a list of products to be liberalized for each country. Other trade issues, including economic cooperation, legal systems, trade barriers and e-commerce will also be on the agenda. 
"We are not sure what the outcome will be at this stage, but we hope there will be good progress. Expectations are high. This is an important and critical round as we will be reporting to the leaders at the ASEAN Summit next month," a Malaysian official attending the Busan meeting told the country's English newspaper The Star on Monday (para. 1-7). Tang, K. (2016). RCEP: The next trade deal you need to know about
http://www.cnbc.com/2015/10/14/tpp-deal-pressures-rcep-trade-talks-in-busan-china-keen-for-progress.html
All bets are off in trade talk due to American election campaign.

The RCEP’s potential future as a major trade bloc will remain uncertain until there is enough political will to go through the arduous negotiation rounds. The RCEP will no doubt face stiff opposition from various interest groups within the participating countries. But now that India has decided to join, it will need to balance economic and strategic calculations and prepare to lead in the “Indo-Pacific century”.

Nakashima (2016) states that: The Treasury Department and Justice Department took actions Monday against four Chinese individuals and one Chinese company for conspiring to aid North Korea’s nuclear weapons program in violation of U.S. economic sanctions.
The unsealing of criminal charges and the imposition of new sanctions are aimed at shutting down a major Chinese node supporting North Korea’s weapons proliferation, officials said.
The Justice Department charged the individuals and the trading company with conspiring to launder money and with evading sanctions. The four individuals and the company are all located in China.
The Treasury Department also imposed sanctions against the firm, Dandong Hongxiang Industrial Development Co. Ltd. (DHID), and the individuals, including Ma Xiaohong, DHID’s majority owner. Ma lives in Dandong, China, on the border with North Korea. She has conducted business with that country since 1996 and stood to benefit the most financially by the transactions, the government said.
The actions come almost seven months after the U.N. Security Council, which includes China, unanimously adopted harsh sanctions against Pyongyang to pressure it to abandon its nuclear weapons program (para. 1-4).
Nakashima, E. (2016). U.S. charges four Chinese, firm with aiding Pyongyang’s nuclear program. The Washington Post. National Security. Retrieved from

However, RCEP leaders failed to come up with a deadline for the mega regional trade pact that has only become more complicated after 14 rounds of negotiations and four ministerial meetings.
For India, RCEP presents a decisive platform to influence its strategic and economic status in the Asia-Pacific region. Leaders of 16 countries in Asia-Pacific called on Thursday for the swift conclusion of negotiations to form the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), an ambitious new trade pact backed by China.
The 10 member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and Australia, China, India, Japan, South Korea and New Zealand vowed to intensify their efforts to conclude talks on the free trade agreement that would encompass 3.4 billion people and account for 30 percent of global economic output (¶ 1-3). Weijia (2016) states that: Some scholars believe that the China-led Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) - an ambitious free trade agreement aimed at promoting economic integration among 16 nations in the Asia-Pacific region - will steal the limelight at the ongoing Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) summit from the US-backed Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). However, it won't be easy to achieve this. The RCEP negotiations, launched during the 21st ASEAN summit in November 2012, has been given too much symbolic meaning. Some people view the talks of the TPP and RCEP as Washington's and Beijing's efforts to distinguish each other's circle of friends. Additionally, the RCEP has received an increasing amount of attention from the world as it will boost stronger economic ties among big powers including Japan, China and India. It is precisely because of this symbolic meaning that the RCEP negotiations face severe challenges from a geopolitical perspective. Some RCEP members lack mutual political trust or have been affected by territorial disputes. For instance, conflicts surrounding the South China Sea have damaged China's ties with some Southeast Asian countries, such as the Philippines. Additionally, competition between India and China is a sensitive topic. It is clear that nationalist sentiment, which can be agitated by any of the conflicts among RCEP members, will be an obstacle in completing the RCEP negotiations (¶1-3). Weijia, H. (2016). Asia-Pacific regional order needs to be reconsidered for RCEP negotiations. Global Times. Retrieved from
http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1005283.shtml

Kyodo News (2016) state that: VIENTIANE - The countries involved in negotiating Asia's most ambitious trade agreement will skip their declared goal of concluding the negotiations by the end of this year and will try to intensify negotiations, official sources said Wednesday.
Leaders from the 16 countries negotiating the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership agreement (RCEP) will say that they "will accelerate the negotiation for the swift conclusion without indicating time or date," in a statement on the progress and future direction of the RCEP talks that they are expected to issue on Thursday afternoon, one source said (¶ 1-2). "Based on the instruction of quicken the work and try to finish the negotiation of RCEP before the end of 2016, the ministers stressed the importance of pushing the negotiation in the coming negotiation of RECP and trying to reach an agreement of high quality as soon as possible according to RCEP Negotiation Guidelines and Objectives. The ministers also gave strategic and targeted suggestions, especially on the core areas like cargo, service and investment. They urged the member countries to keep participating in the negotiation in a positive and constructive attitude" http://www.asiantradecentre.org/talkingtrade//rcep-status-update
"There are four potential outcomes for RCEP at this point. 
First, RCEP could simply fail.  This would be deeply problematic, but not entirely unexpected.  In a time period when trade is facing strong headwinds in many places, getting a large Megaregional off the ground is tough.  RCEP members have massive gaps in every conceivable dimension.  Toss in new political and security tensions and the glue holding together these diverse 16 countries may be insufficiently strong to get a result.
Second, RCEP could conclude as planned at the end of the year.  The agreement will not be good.  There is physically too much to do and too little time to do it well.  Leaders could certainly fudge the issue and leave the deal in the “legal scrub” or “translation” for one-two years while officials race to nail down all the details.  But this is risky since talks could actually derail if the agreement is not really close to conclusion.
Third, RCEP could close with a “built-in agenda.”  This would allow the talks to finish on schedule and let talks continue on everything that is not done.  But ASEAN’s track record of built-in agendas is not great.  As a case in point, the very first item on the AEC Blueprint 2025 is to conclude everything not finished in the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) in 2016 but progress has been glacial as July draws to a close. 
Fourth, RCEP could announce an “early harvest” and keep negotiating through 2017.  This is not a desirable outcome for many dialogue partners who want to keep up the momentum for a higher quality outcome.  But the pressure for some sort of concrete result is high, particularly for some RCEP parties.  Hence a small, comprehensive package (ATC suggests this one) might be worthwhile to consider that does not dilute the interest of most members to keep talking."

http://www.ictsd.org/bridges-news/bridges/news/rcep-countries-conclude-auckland-round-eye-next-steps " . . .  the pace of the talks to date have led some observers to speculate that this process could drag on past the end-2016 target.
. . .
" . . .   all RCEP countries have now submitted initial offers both for goods and services trade, as well as initial lists of reservations for investment. There have also been requests submitted relating to goods and services by most RCEP countries, along with some requests for initial reservations on investment, officials added. " . . .  Discussions over Mode 4 – those services commitments that involve the movement of natural persons – also continue, with some countries showing a strong interest and others presenting constraints given their immigration policies. "Meanwhile, talks on investment liberalisation are following a negative list approach, in which all industry sectors are open to investment unless specifically deemed as closed. "Whether government procurement will be included in a final RCEP deal is currently under discussion in a sub-working group, with a final decision not yet confirmed. While it was not listed in the original “guiding principles,” that document does have a section on “other issues,” where topics that some RCEP members have covered in other FTAs can be raised for possible discussion, and potentially agreement. "Regarding RCEP draft texts, officials reported progress in the latest round, though more remains to be done. Negotiators are also working to establish terms for a dispute settlement mechanism under the working group in charge of legal and institutional aspects.  " . . .  negotiations are considering transparency as well as facilitating customs procedures and enhancing trade facilitation, especially addressing NTMs and technical barriers to trade (TBT). There has also been a proposal for a dedicated chapter on trade facilitation. "According to Trainor, some provisions that are not addressed in the WTO’s Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA) are still under negotiation in RCEP, including some aimed at making SMEs’ exports cross borders expeditiously. The TFA is currently in the ratification process and is not yet in force. "RCEP negotiations are also taking place on rules of origin and competition as other ways to facilitate SMEs’ participation in trade, along with e-commerce. 
. . .
" . . .  the goal of clinching a deal by year’s end . . .would likely be the earliest for reaching a possible deal. "One complicating factor is that not all participating countries have an FTA with their RCEP partners. For example, there is no FTA between China and India, although both countries have been considering a potential agreement since 2003. There is also no FTA between China and Japan, although the China-Japan-Korea FTA is under negotiation. (See Bridges Weekly, 5 November 2015)  As a result, RCEP negotiations need not only to construct a large regional agreement but also build FTA relationships that currently do not exist. Participating countries also have different levels of economic development, which some say could further complicate the process.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I note that negotiators have just received all drafts, and that the report mentions "initial" offers and lists, requests, the possibility of additional issues, consideration of proposals and that not all participating countries have an FTA with their RCEP partners, all of which sounds to me like the negotiations are in the very earliest stages.  As the report says, the process could extend into 2016.

http://www.financialexpress.com/article/fe-columnist/will-india-lead-the-indo-pacific-century/272672/ " . . . the serious adverse effects of joining the agreement have made India more aggressive in the ongoing negotiations. It is said that India is seeking greater market access in services to be able to justify the closing of the deal at home, where an apprehensive local industry views it as equivalent to signing an FTA with China. This has been the norm and a problem that India has faced since it started negotiating regional trade agreements (RTAs) and RCEP is no exception.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  India was the fly in the ointment of the WTO trade agreement for YEARS and it sounds like it is still as problematic as ever.

The Indian government is fully aware that once these sectors are open to foreign entry and competition, such sensitive sectors will have deep repercussions on the economic livelihood, farmers’ welfare and agricultural productivity of the nation." http://www.deccanherald.com/content/549078/devise-realistic-strategy.html

It is practically an iron law of trade agreements that when negotiations are "almost complete," they can stay that way for a real long time.  Those last few details are always put off because they affect highly influential special interest groups within one or more polities whose interests are just about diametrically opposed to everyone else's, including their own governments'.   This one could still get done in '16, though.

The "consensus" has dropped sharply from 72% a month ago to 47% today, though I can't see why. Formal negotiations are set to continue for another two rounds in June and September, and there was a proposal from India a couple of months ago to have informal meetings in between to tackle sticking points. India is always a tough negotiator but I get the impression it wants this agreement even though there is some domestic opposition.  One important issue remaining seems to be patents especially on medicines, and intellectual property rights in general. The two links below indicate this might be India's focus for the next meetings. I expect India to negotiate hard but not to the extent of torpedoing a final agreement. http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/op-ed/standing-up-to-patent-bullying/article8630566.ece
"The Ministry of Commerce must be cautious of Free Trade Agreements (FTAs), such as the ones it is presently negotiating with the European Union as well as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), that further strengthen or extend intellectual property monopolies. These will subsequently delay generic competition and the associated drop in prices, which will have a negative impact upon access to affordable medicines from domestic producers."
and
http://www.eastasiaforum.org/2016/05/20/is-india-holding-the-line-against-another-tpp/
"Of the RCEP negotiating countries, it is India, rather than China, that has been the most outspoken in opposing US-style trade rules. In the lead up to the Perth talks, rumours were swirling that the Indian negotiators had been handed an ultimatum by their RCEP partners: play ball or leave the group. The Indian Minister of Commerce denied that any such ultimatum had been made, but the tensions between India and some of the other major players have been evident for some time.
Much of the discussion in the media has suggested that the conflict is primarily over traditional trade issues like cutting tariffs. But recently leaked draft RCEP chapters also indicate a lack of consensus on intellectual property and investment, with India and in some cases ASEAN clearly at odds with South Korea and Japan, who are pushing for protections similar to those in the TPP."

While it is true that negotiators passed the TPP, that does not guarantee legislative confirmation. So, I'm not sure that TPP's status is putting that much pressure on RCEP. I still believe there are unspoken issues related to South China Sea territorial conflicts that is causing some countries to slow-walk this agreement. Then, of course, there are the details themselves that need resolution such as whether there will be an ISDS (investor-state dispute settlement) mechanism.
So, nothing happened in Perth. Nothing becomes the likely result.
This looks like it could take quite a while! Very little of substance has been negotiated yet and the politicians still have to get involved.

http://www.livemint.com/Politics/37pnX4pjCINPeglF6d53HL/RCEP-negotiations-India-likely-to-take-a-more-aggressive-st.html New Delhi: "An internal commerce ministry estimate that signing the 16-country Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) trade agreement will result in a revenue loss of as much as 1.6% of gross domestic product has alarmed officials.  This is expected to make India more aggressive in the upcoming negotiations, seeking greater market access in services to be able to justify the closing of the deal at home, where an apprehensive local industry views it as equivalent to signing a free trade agreement with China. "The next round of RCEP negotiation will take place in Perth, Australia, during 23-29 April. "A commerce ministry official said India will quote its revenue loss figure and ask other countries how much they are sacrificing. “While their definition of a balanced outcome is if everybody’s tariff lines come to zero, we think from what level you bring down your tariffs to zero is important. Secondly, if I am sacrificing this much revenue, how much are other countries sacrificing? These are questions that will certainly be asked inside negotiating rooms. Why a trade negotiation should be completed without proper balance in the deal,” the official said, on condition of anonymity. The official said that if balance cannot be achieved in goods, other countries need to give greater market access to services from India. “If you don’t want to give anything in services and the goods deal is also not balanced, then why should I sign the deal? What is my hurry to complete it? Ultimate issue will always be whether the price is right,” he added. "India, due to its higher tariff wall, ends up cutting its tariffs more significantly in such bilateral or plurilateral trade negotiations, while other countries, due to their already low tariff lines, need only to reduce them marginally. India thinks its best bet is in services export, through which it can supply its burgeoning skilled professionals to other countries, thus partially meeting the demand for jobs from a million people joining the labour market every month.
. . . 
"India is also seeking a visa on arrival regime for business travel and tourism with the 16 RCEP member countries. “Asean (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) countries provide visa-free travel among themselves and also to some countries outside Asean region. We are saying if you are doing a comprehensive agreement on RCEP, if you don’t give us similar benefits, then what are you discussing with us?” the official said.
~~~~~~~

I would start high on this question as the 'final' session is scheduled for September, which leaves some time for last minute rounds to iron out the wrinkles. The recently concluded TPP also puts pressure on the non-TPP countries to see the process through so as not to be left behind. Recent doldrums for world trade will also act as a push to get the deal done. Since ratification is not needed, it should be possible to get an agreement in place. Negatives - India has been a tough negotiator in the past, but I have a feeling they will be more amenable to a deal this time. Don't know much about Indonesia, which is the other country that could pose a problem for the deal. China might also derail the process due to developments in the South China sea. Major negative is that no country is seen as owning and driving the RCEP process. So if it gets stuck on some minor issues, there could be delays. If we don't get some definite positive news emerging by September, will have lowered this to 30-40% by that time.

Reducing from 75 last month, for passage of time. The next round starts 22 April in Perth, Australia, but it's worth remembering that negotiations have been in progress since November 2012. The article copied below is from the Indian perspective and shows there is still a long way to go.  http://www.bilaterals.org/?next-round-of-rcep-negotiations-in "The next round of negotiations for the proposed mega trade deal, Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), would take place in April in Australia. In the meeting, India is expected to press for greater market access in services sector, particularly easy movement of professionals, an official said. "The 11th round of talks was concluded last month in Brunei. The 12th round of negotiations is scheduled at Perth in Australia from April 22," the official said. Besides liberalisation of the services sector, the other issues, which may come up in the talks include matters related to goods tariffs. "In the goods sector, India has asked the members to fulfil their commitments as their current offers are not up to the level they have committed," the official added. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) is a mega trade deal which aims to cover goods, services, investments, economic and technical cooperation, competition and intellectual property rights. As part of its goods proposal, India has not offered any duty cut on steel to China, Australia and New Zealand in the proposed free trade agreement among 16 Asian members. The RCEP talks started in Phnom Penh in November 2012. The 16 countries account for over a quarter of the world’s economy, estimated to be more than USD 75 trillion. The RCEP deal is also important amidst the Trans Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement led by the US. Indian industry is apprehensive that TPP would impact Indian exports. India already has free trade agreements (FTAs) with the Asean grouping, Japan and South Korea. India has offered to open its market the most for Asean countries — with which it has an FTA in place — and has proposed to eliminate duties or tariffs on 80 per cent of items for the 10-nation bloc. Similarly, for Japan and South Korea, it has offered to open up 65 per cent of its product space. For Australia, New Zealand and China, Delhi has proposed to eliminate duties on only 42.5 per cent of products. As India does not have any kind of FTA with these three countries, its offer is less. The 16-member bloc RCEP comprises 10 Asean members (Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Malaysia, Myanmar, Singapore, Thailand, the Philippines, Laos and Vietnam) and their six free trade agreement partners — India, China, Japan, South Korea, Australia and New Zealand. Source: The Economic Times"

Mar 5: "RCEP talks to stretch longer on differences over services" --> http://www.financialexpress.com/article/economy/rcep-talks-to-stretch-longer-on-differences-over-services/219805/ The negotiations for the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) involving 16 countries could slow down in the coming months due to a lack of consensus over services. Some members are unwilling to show flexibility in discussing liberalisation of the services sector, and are instead seeking more relaxation in goods, while India wants a greater commitment from them on services, as it has shown in offering to remove barriers in goods trade, sources told FE. India will likely step up its demand for a deal on services in Perth in Australia where the 12th round of RCEP negotiations are scheduled to take place from April 22. The absence of a consensus on services may further delay the negotiations, which have already missed the 2015 deadline for conclusion, even as pressure piles up on the bloc to clinch a deal following the Trans-Pacific Partnership between the US and 11 other countries. India is of the opinion that a liberalisation of services, such as further relaxation in visa regime for a freer movement of professionals, should be addressed along with that of goods, while some other members seem to be interested only in goods, they added. The country is keen on services, as they account for over a half of its GDP. Some of these members want that a clear-cut ministerial mandate has to be reached first on services at the RCEP before such issues can be taken up, while India argues that even the current mandate doesn’t prevent any discussion on them, said the sources. India is also miffed that while it has taken its initial offer of removing import duties on 42.5% of tariff lines on goods seriously, many Asean nations that are part of the negotiations haven’t progressed much on their offers. The movement of natural persons is one of the four ways through which services can be supplied internationally. Also known as “Mode 4”, it covers natural persons who are either service suppliers (such as independent professionals) or who work for a service supplier and who are present in another member to supply a service. India has a vast pool of skilled workers, especially in the IT sector.

There is a 0% probability the negotiations conclude by the original deadline in June. And, I estimate more than a 51% probability they are completed by December. 
Equal premise restated in the obverse:
100% probability they will not be completed by the deadline in June. And, I estimate less than a 49% probability they will fail to conclude by December. What does this mean if that is true AND a forecast an 85% probability now is true? 1. Given an additional 182 days after June's 'deadline' with the same respective base-rates the absolute likelihood of occurrences increases but not respective rates so the probabilities are unchanged.  51% to 49% today is equivalent to the same at the end of the year.  So, why am I at 85% today and not 51%?
Example: Both of these are true.  But the increase is proportionately the same respective to the other.
-> Given more time (i.e. June to December) there is a greater likelihood a negotiation would fall apart. 
-> Given more time (i.e. June to December)  there is a greater likelihood a negotiation would conclude successfully. 2. Given this is March the negotiators have the opportunity to take constructive/purposeful action before the announcement in June.  I anticipate the June announcement will include a status report.  Reporting on the status of each parties position at the original deadline is a constructive action-forcing mechanism.  Therefore:
-> The fact that another 'deadline' in June will be transgressed in a positive motivating factor to push the parties to build a compromise and report progress.  
-> A VERY slight increase now, anticipation of a reckoning in June, results in a very large change in my prediction over 10 months (i.e. from 51% to 85% currently)

COMMENTS:
The current meeting is Round 11 since May 2013.   The folks that take part in negotiating trade deals know all about the art of making deals and put out all sorts of signals during the process that may bear no relationship to reality, but do something to enhance their bargaining position or satisfy some political constituency, so I take statements with a ton of salt. My baseline rule is that the more countries involved, the longer it takes.  TPP involved fewer (12) countries and took 7 years. The reports were "soon and very soon" for about 2 years before it actually was completed, with relatively detailed descriptions of what the remaining issues were. I note that this report includes no specifics about how long it might take to create the regional value chains and production network that are deemed necessary. Therefore, I am going conservatively "no" on this by forecasting 50% for now (in case I'm loony) and everyone else is right.

RCEP negotiations are taking place in Brunei this week.  CNBC article on India's interest in the RCEP.  India's exclusion from ASEAN has hopefully been excruciatingly painful so they don't squander this economic opportunity like usual.  New leadership, new day   : )
--  
year.......export.....import.....trade deficit
2012........298.4.....	500.4........-202.0
2013........313.2.....	467.5........-154.3
2014........318.2.....	462.9........-144.7
2015........310.3.....	447.9........-137.6 Couple large incentives for India this time around:
(1) trade deficits and no doubt going to be huge this year since India's top export is oil (19%). 
(2) desperation for regional export markets.  None of India's top ten export markets are in the West, save for China/Hong Kong.  Their awesome non-diversification and complete susceptibility to China's slowing economy make me believe India is, for once, serious about economic growth. 
--
India's 2013 currency crisis and devaluation was actually helpful, as I read, since their leadership said they haven't been hit by the global slowdown yet.  Which is not surprising given that they have a pretty isolationist political structure, dovish monetary policy, beggar thy neighbor currency, and asset bubbles as a result.  Their exports are mainly tied to Europe (recessionary/deflationary) and China (currently in a hard landing) so the outlook isn't good without expanding their export markets : ) http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-01-22/low-interest-rates-creating-next-economic-crisis/7106958 --
http://www.cnbc.com/2016/02/10/reuters-america-with-tpp-advancing-india-pins-hopes-on-china-backed-trade-bloc.html

I'm skeptical that any such negotiation will slip just 3 months past its initial schedule. If time were generally good, I'd be more positive. However, we might see Japan and China in a competitive devaluation this year, and an all-around tendency to pull-back into nationalist rhetoric rather than to engage. So, I'm going to buck the consensus a wee bit and give this even odds of ending this year. 
Could change, depending on the news that comes out from the talks being held in Brunei right now.
Will also change if the world economy sours: the sweeter things are, the more likely we see a deal.

When one hears the words "deflation", I'll bet you think 1930's depression in the U.S. and the misery in the Weimar Republic  (now Germany). 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Depression
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weimar_Republic But one of the contributors to the depression was global trade wars.  Looking up the Smoot-Hawley tariff and how global trade contributes to global deflationary fears I was happy to learn that more trade is good and isolationism isn't.

Here's my working thesis for 2016-2017: Global deflation resulting from Central Bank QE leading to massive over-investment & currency crisis A potential deflationary recessionary cycle is scary on a level and magnitude that honestly it difficult to think about. But, like death, economic depressions happen  : ( 
-- 
So you're one of the countries facing this scenario and creating a trade deal.....     Are you going to get it done or get nit-picky about the details?  
.........(a) negative sovereign rates ( Japan, German, Switzerland, etc etc ) 
.........(b) yuan devaluation ( smart money around 30-40% devaluation by the end of the year ) 
.........(c) China's liquidity crunch in foreign-exchange reserves ( approx. $3.23 trillion maybe 1/2 what's needed ) 
.........(d) deflationary oil pricing from massive oversupply driving down U.S. industrial sector and spreading into debt market as energy companies fail around the world 
.........(e) U.S. treasuries rates going negative along with the rest of sovereign debt (bad sign of deflation ) 
.........(f) Major bank (i.e. Deutsche Bank) defaults or else liquidating it's equity so as not to default (i.e. stock value of $1) and Germany having to step in to back it to stop an all out backing crisis and run on the bank 
.........(g) Global Currency Crisis: China's $3.5 trillion banking problem potential -> 30-40% Yuan devaluation ->  a global liquidity crisis.

I'll state a platitude: FTA are now used as much for environmental and human rights policy implementation than trade any more (that's what college course text books say any way ) so my rationalization for being overly optimistic at the moment is simply that global politics (save for China, which dooms the TPP) makes the RCEP more desirable since Chinese aggression within the region and economic decisions are coalescing support around China policy.

As an aside, I was chatting with a friend in Australia yesterday & that was my take away.  Australia's dependence on China made them vulnerable so RCEP is good

predictions on this IFP are pretty thin so I'm not predicting as high as I otherwise would.  I think we'll know more after the 11th round to take place in Brunei February 15th-19th.  The RCEP isn't politically feasible if the Republicans win the U.S. presidential election in my opinion.  So this gives the RCEP till November to get their shit together and push through whatever they have at the time.  That said, U.S. congress are going to need to sign on without "fast track" authority and I don't see that happening in a Republican controlled congress. --
A good source I found to get started: http://www.asiantradecentre.org/  There report for the RCEP included this paragraph:
"More important for firms—officials basically have one shot at this agreement.  It is quite rare for governments to sit down in the future and engage in a wholesale revision of an existing agreement.  Whatever comes out of the RCEP process is likely to be the trade agreement across Asia for at least the next decade.  Hence, company engagement with governments at the level of individual members and the group is critical to crafting the best possible deal for the future." source:http://www.asiantradecentre.org/talkingtrade/2016/1/19/trade-outlook-for-2016?rq=RCEP%2C%202016

I'll risk being overly confident on this since the final meeting is "planned" for September ( assuming ratification isn't required).  GATT took only 6 months and was fairly complex so I guess I'm willing to be overly confident that the parties want the deal completed in a timely manner so they will.

While there is significant pressure to reach an agreement there are several items that reduce my confidence agreement being reached. Most concerning is the lack of clarity on the negotiations. If the business community has concerns then that could delay negotiations. Additionally, there are a number of concerns regarding the relationships between the ASEAN countries (water and border disputes are common).

Forecast Upward: Smaller, more focused meetings for next round. Bodes well for some progress.
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/economy/policy/rcep-agreement-eye-on-essential-pillars-meetings-to-be-smaller-and-more-focussed/articleshow/50750014.cms

Heads of state of participating countries are keen to see a deal. The completion of TPP has gives the negotiations a sense of urgency, and also frees negotiators working on both deals to focus on RCEP. The open issues don't present any problems that can't be overcome in 11 months.
16 parties and 4 rounds to complete in 11 months?  Too many contingencies, even if ratification is unnecessary for the question.

A lot of progress has been made in order to finalize this agreement.  Additionally, the upcoming 4 rounds are all going to be completed by mid to late 2016, with the 'final' one being in september.  This gives a lag time of nearly 3 months to finalize any last details and sign the agreement.  Given that ratification is NOT needed for this question, I feel comfortable placing it at a fairly high number.  That being said, I never trust international organizations fully to complete anything on time, making me unwilling to bump this higher.

I thought it might be useful to see how other treaties worked out in terms of time and number of members.  Agreement  /   Start of Negotiations	          /             Signed       /      #Countries
NAFTA		 /              1990			 /              1992 (2yrs)		/    3
TPSEP	         /              2002			/               2005 (3 yrs)      /          4
TPP                 /               2008			/               2015 (7yrs)      /         12 RCEP	       /                 2012                    /                NA  (4TH YEAR)        16 Remaining Rounds for RCEP:
Round 11: 15–19 February 2016 in Brunei.
Round 12: April 2016 Location in Perth, Australia
Round 13: June 2016 Location in New Zealand
Round 14: & "Final": September 2016 Location in Laos Based on a cursory review of selected news items, it seems the agreement is on track for completion. If the negotiations bring resolution to the remaining issues, then the RCEP agreement should be finalized late this year. Yet, there are 4 more rounds scheduled. And the remaining issues are the most contentious.  And there are 16 countries involved in very sensitive negotiations. So, these considerations point to a more reserved probability for a positive outcome by the end of the year. The news items also indicate that the signing of the TPP created a sense of urgency for those negotiating the RCEP. So, one would expect that the RCEP participants are eager to conclude the agreement to gain perceived benefits.  As the rounds conclude, I’ll adjust my forecast accordingly.   Current Forecast: 70%
Conflicting interests here - getting China, Japan, Korea & India to agree is never easy - I note the 4 meetings set up already to advance this - will update as we get more information here.
China's instability will force its neighbors to seek security.
All that remains is the resolution details. (easier said than done.)
The commodity rout may be a driving force leading to an agreement on the RCEP in 2016.

Everybody is always optimistic about trade talks they're involved in.  Everybody is always wrong.  Sooner or later, talks are successful or abandoned, but in the meantime there is no theoretical limit on how long they can continue.  When folks say they're down to the last x% of issues, you know they're in for a long slog, because they've already dealt with the easy stuff, which is 100-x%.  Eventually, politics trumps economics one direction or the other.  Too soon to tell on this one yet, but let's give them the benefit of the doubt, in case it really is a benefit.

Starting with this one at 96%. There seems to be a lot of "positivity" about this being finished by the end of the year. Plus, as @morrell (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/99407) astutely observed, there are four meetings scheduled this year with the "Final" one coming in September, which leaves room for the possibility of another meeting in Oct/Nov/Dec, if they haven't quite hammered everything out. Here's the Wiki page, if you're interested --> https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_Comprehensive_Economic_Partnership And the dates of the four meetings this year: Round 11: 15–19 February 2016 in Brunei.
Round 12: April 2016 Location in Perth, Australia
Round 13: June 2016 Location in New Zealand
Round 14 & "Final": September 2016 Location in Laos

Four meetings scheduled this year, (Feb, April, June, September) with Sept marked "Final."  Having fourth meeting in Sept also allows possibility of fitting in another before the end of the year if necessary. Seems likely that the last bit of negotiations could be completed - intent was to finish by the end of 2015.  But - worth checking this after that Feb meeting (scheduled for 2/15 - 2/19 in Brunei).

It behooves all countries involved to complete the agreement because of the present economic situation across the world.

IPR's and e-commerce are major factors holding up this agreement Initial assessment is positive this agreement will be reached in 2016 due to non-ASEAN members influence to get this done. Also, will the recent economic downturn of China have a negative or positive effect on this agreement? Will look into this deeper when ASEAN members meet in the beginning of February.

There is some conflict between RCEP and TPP (http://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/publication/152753/reiwp-146.pdf).  The ASEAN community has multiple, Bi-lateral, Free Trade Agreements (FTA), so goal of RCEP is to find a common base. One set of difficulties is the reduction of the differing FTA tariffs. Some analysts indicate this as a significant hurdle. In order to jump it, countries will need to water-down the tariff reductions, which essentially waters-down the whole RCEP. It seems likely, that some RCEP agreement is reached by end of 2016 even if it doesn't reach its loftiest goals. Interesting background: http://asiafoundation.org/in-asia/2015/09/09/tpp-and-rcep-boon-or-bane-for-asean/

In October 2015, it was reported that only 15% of the thousands of products being discussed remained to be agreed. However, these were "sensitive items".  Such agreements have historically taken much longer than anticipated, but the coming year should be enough - and the schedule for talks has the "Final" round in September this year, after meetings in February, April and June. In favor of completion this year is that China and India will be wanting this to counterbalance the TTP from which they are currently excluded. Against is that India is a notoriously difficult negotiator given to holding out till the last minute and beyond. There'll be time enough to adjust if necessary in the coming months after seeing how the next couple of meetings progress.

The schedule is for an agreement to reached in September.  The crowd estimates are high, but there have been many previous delays.  I'm going to start with a 65% estimate, slightly increased for gaming.
Feb mtg next round with Post Sept wrap up after asean ministerial mtg .
Seems to be as on track as any such endeavour can be at this point, but a lot of stuff can go over the thing in a year.  One can pontificate with more confidence in maybe April.
